tool.name: SOAPsplice
tool.command:
soapsplice.py
## Reference source --fileSource=$genomeSource.refGenomeSource #if $genomeSource.refGenomeSource == "history": ##build index on the fly --ref="${genomeSource.ownFile}" --dbkey=$dbkey #else: ##use precomputed indexes --ref="${genomeSource.indices.fields.path}" --do_not_build_index #end if
## Input file(s) --input1=$paired.input1 #if $paired.sPaired == "paired": --input2=$paired.input2 #end if
## Prefix of output files which can contain a file directory ##--output_dir_prefix=$output_dir_prefix
## Insert length --insert_length=$insert_length
## Output files for paired-end reads input data sets --forward_2segs=$forward_2segs --forward_out=$forward_out --reverse_2segs=$reverse_2segs 1 --reverse_out=$reverse_out --junction=$junction
## Check if using default or custom parameters --default_full_settings_type=$default_full_settings.settings_type #if $default_full_settings.settings_type == "full" --num_threads=$num_threads --forward_reverse_both=$forward_reverse_both --max_mismatch=$max_mismatch --max_indel=$max_indel --ignore_tail_length=$ignore_tail_length --longest_gap_length=longest_gap_length --shortest_segment_length=$shortest_segment_length --output_read_and_quality=$output_read_and_quality --output_format=$output_format #if $output_format == "2": --set_mapq=$set_mapq #end if --input_quality_type=$input_quality_type ## For output junctions --max_distance_bet_paired_ends=$max_distance_bet_paired_ends --min_distance_bet_paired_ends=$min_distance_bet_paired_ends --output_junction_info=$output_junction_info #end if

param.name: refGenomeSource
param.label: Select a reference genome from your history or use a built-in index

param.name: sPaired
param.label: Is your input data set mate-paired?

param.name: settings_type
param.label: SOAPsplice settings to use
param.help: For most mapping needs, please use Default settings. If you want full control then use Full Parameter List

param.name: ignore_tail_length
param.label: Length of tail that can be ignored in one-segment alignment

param.name: longest_gap_length
param.label: Longest gap between two segments in two-segment alignment

param.name: shortest_segment_length
param.label: Shortest length of a segment in two-segment alignment

param.name: input_quality_type
param.label: Input quality type in FASTQ file
param.option: quality = Phred + 64, used in Illumina/Solexa format
quality = Phred + 33, used in Sanger format

data.name: forward_2segs
data.label: Two segment alignment for forward set of reads

data.name: forward_out
data.label: One segment alignment for forward set of reads

data.name: reverse_2segs
data.label: Two segment alignment for reverse set of reads

data.name: reverse_out
data.label: One segment alignment for reverse set of reads

tool.help:
**What it does**
SOAPsplice is a tool for the genome-wide ab initio detection of splice junction sites from RNA-Seq data. The tool performs better than the previous tools by detecting similar number of true junctions with lower false positives as the best performing tool in all different situations with different read lengths and coverage. In particular, SOAPsplice performs better by predicting more true junctions with low false positive rate when the coverage is low, which is useful for detecting the junctions for those mRNAs with relatively lower expression level. For more information, please refer to the part of "Performance Evaluation" in this page. SOAPsplice is free for academic use only.
-----
**How it works**
To use SOAPsplice, short reads are searched against index files for a given reference genome are required. A selection of index files are available from the above drop down menu which have been built for use with BGI SOAP tools using the 2bwt-builder tool.
-----
**Outputs**
Three types of output files are generated by SOAPsplice:
1. One-segment alignment files which end in .out 2. Two-segment alignment files which end in .2Segs 3. A single junction file that ends in .junc
The one-segment alignment output file has the following columns::
Column Description ---------- -------------------------------------------------------- index Number i means it is ith read id The id of the read seq Sequence of mapped bases. The read will be converted to the reverse complement of the sequence if mapped on the reverse chain of reference qual Quality of sequence. Corresponding to sequence, to be consistent with seq, it will be converted too if mapped on reverse chain num hits Number of equal best hits. The reads with no hits will be ignored length Length of mapped bases +/- Alignment on the direct (+) or reverse (-) chain of the reference chr Id of reference sequence location Location of first bp on the reference, counted from 1 types Type of hits: 0: exact match. 1~3 RefAllele->OffsetQueryAlleleQual: number of mismatches, followed by detailed mutation sites and switch of allele types. Offset is relative to the initial location on reference. 'OffsetAlleleQual': offset, allele, and quality. "1INDEL", "2INDEL": alignment with 1 or 2 indels. Example: "2 A->10T30 C->13A32" means there are two mismatches, one on location+10 of the reference, and the other on location+13 of reference. The alleles on reference are A and C respectively, while query alleles and their quality are T, 30 and A, 32.
Two-segment alignment files end with a .2Segs suffix and contain the following columns::
Column Description ---------- -------------------------------------------------------- index Number i means it's ith read id The id of the read; hitOne,hitTwo Number of equal best hits for both segments lengthOne,etc The length for both segments +/- Alignment on the direct (+) or reverse (-) chain of the reference direction The chain that the junction reported by this read is on, "fwd" means it's on the direct chain, while "rev" means it's on the reverse chain; chrOne,etc Id of reference sequence that both segments align to locationOne,etc Location of first bp on the reference for both segments, counted from 1 mismatchOne The number of mismatches for both segments, at most 1 for each segment mismatchInfo The same as last column in one-segment alignment file.
Junction files with a .junc suffix contain the following columns::
Column Description ---------- -------------------------------------------------------- chr Id of reference sequence that the junction comes from site1 Left site of the junction site, one previous the left bound of the intron site2 Right site of the junction site, one after the right round of the intron direction The chain that the intron is on, "fwd" means it's on the direct chain, while "rev" means it's on the reverse chain. number Number of reads supporting this junction.
-----
**Publication**
Huang S, Zhang J, Li R, Zhang W, He Z, Lam T-W, Peng Z and Yiu S-M (2011) SOAPsplice: genome-wide ab initio detection of splice junctions from RNA-Seq data. Front. Gene. 2:46. doi: 10.3389/fgene.2011.00046
-----
**References**
1. Li, H., J. Ruan, et al. (2008). "Mapping short DNA sequencing reads and calling variants using mapping quality scores." Genome Res 18(11): 1851-8. 2. Wang, E. T., R. Sandberg, et al. (2008). "Alternative isoform regulation in human tissue transcriptomes." Nature 456(7221): 470-6. 3. Trapnell, C., L. Pachter, et al. (2009). "TopHat: discovering splice junctions with RNA-Seq." Bioinformatics 25(9): 1105-11. 4. Au, Kin Fai, Jiang, Hui, Lin, Lan, Xing, Yi, Wong, Wing Hung (2010). "Detection of splice junctions from paired-end RNA-seq data by SpliceMap." Nucleic Acids Research 38(14), 4570-4578. 5. Wang, Kai et al. (2010). "MapSplice: accurate mapping of RNA-seq reads for splice junction discovery." Nucleic Acids Research 38(18), e178, doi:10.1093/nar/gkq622.
